problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized as objective
Assignment of each item to a box
X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

objective:
# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> int:
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)
constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        item_w: int = items[i].width
        item_h: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        assert pos_x + item_w <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert pos_y + item_h <= BOX_HEIGHT

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                xi: int = positions[i].x
                yi: int = positions[i].y
                wi: int = items[i].width
                hi: int = items[i].height
                xj: int = positions[j].x
                yj: int = positions[j].y
                wj: int = items[j].width
                hj: int = items[j].height
                assert xi + wi <= xj or xj + wj <= xi or yi + hi <= yj or yj + hj <= yi

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        assert box_id >= 1
        assert box_id <= 10
        assert pos_x >= 0
        assert pos_x <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert pos_y >= 0
        assert pos_y <= BOX_HEIGHT

ensure_item_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=13),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=12)
})

# Define the BoxAssignment object type for tracking which box an item is assigned to
BoxAssignment = DSRecord({
    "box_id": DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
})

# Define the Position object type for tracking x,y positions of items
Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=13),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=12)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT : int = 13
BOX_WIDTH : int = 13
ITEMS : DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item) = [
    {"width": 9, "height": 1},
    {"width": 12, "height": 4},
    {"width": 6, "height": 1},
    {"width": 9, "height": 4},
    {"width": 6, "height": 12},
    {"width": 13, "height": 7},
    {"width": 12, "height": 10},
    {"width": 11, "height": 3},
    {"width": 9, "height": 11},
    {"width": 8, "height": 12}
]
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
x_y_positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 10
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 10
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 10


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> int:
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_between_items(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Position)
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check for non-overlapping on x-axis
                x_not_overlap: bool = (positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x) or \
                                      (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x)
                # Check for non-overlapping on y-axis
                y_not_overlap: bool = (positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y) or \
                                      (positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y)
                # Assert that at least one axis does not overlap
                assert x_not_overlap or y_not_overlap

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box.
Position x and y of each item within box

objective:
# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=0, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

):

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box.
Position x and y of each item within box

objective:
# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=0, ub=10):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to place in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, to be minimized
Assignment of each item to a box
X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

        box_id: int = assignments[i].box_id
        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

):

        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        x_pos: int = assignments[i].x

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_in_boxes(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item)
):
    for i in range(1, 11):
        for j in range(i + 1, 11):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            same_box: bool = assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id
            if same_box:
                # Extract values directly to avoid temporary variables for fields
                x1: int = assignments[i].x
                y1: int = assignments[i].y
                w1: int = items[i].width
                h1: int = items[i].height
                
                x2: int = assignments[j].x
                y2: int = assignments[j].y
                w2: int = items[j].width
                h2: int = items[j].height

                # No overlap condition: one of the following must be true:
                # 1. item1 is to the right of item2
                # 2. item2 is to the right of item1
                # 3. item1 is below item2
                # 4. item2 is below item1
                assert (x1 >= x2 + w2) or (x2 >= x1 + w1) or (y1 >= y2 + h2) or (y2 >= y1 + h1)

no_overlap_in_boxes(item_box_assignments, ITEMS)

# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10))) -> int:
    max_box_id: int = 0

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to place in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized in the objective
Assignment of each item to a box with box id
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=10)]], Len(10, 10)]

        if box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = box_id
    return max_box_id

Assignment of each item to a box with box id
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=10)]], Len(10, 10)]

decision_variables.description: X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_consistency(
    assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10)),
    positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i] == positions[i].box_id

ensure_item_assignment_consistency(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)
full_formulation:
# --- Objects ---


Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=13),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=13)
})

BoxAssignment = DSRecord({
    "box_id": DSInt(lb=1, ub=10),
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=13),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=13)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT: int = 13
BOX_WIDTH: int = 13
ITEMS: DSList(length=10, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 9, "height": 1}, {"width": 12, "height": 4}, {"width": 6, "height": 1}, {"width": 9, "height": 4}, {"width": 6, "height": 12}, {"width": 13, "height": 7}, {"width": 12, "height": 10}, {"width": 11, "height": 3}, {"width": 9, "height": 11}, {"width": 8, "height": 12}]
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=0, ub=10)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10))
x_y_positions: DSList(length=10, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
N_ITEMS : int = 10
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 10
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 10


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=10, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=10))) -> int:
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if item_box_assignments[i] > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = item_box_assignments[i]
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)
